claim: A coerced confession may be inadmissible in court

supporting.text: Coerced confessions violate the Fifth Amendment of the U.S. Constitution, which protects against self-incrimination.

attacks.text: Coerced confessions violate the Fifth Amendment of the U.S. Constitution, which protects against self-incrimination.
Some courts have admitted coerced confessions if they are later corroborated by independent evidence.
The 'fruit of the poisonous tree' doctrine generally prohibits the use of evidence derived from coerced confessions, even if corroborated.
The Fifth Amendment only applies to testimonial evidence, not physical evidence obtained through coercion.
Physical evidence obtained as a direct result of a coerced confession may still be excluded under the Fourth Amendment's protections against unreasonable searches.

supporting.text: The Supreme Court has ruled in cases like Miranda v. Arizona that confessions obtained under duress are not voluntary and thus inadmissible.

attacks.text: The Supreme Court has ruled in cases like Miranda v. Arizona that confessions obtained under duress are not voluntary and thus inadmissible.
Some jurisdictions allow coerced confessions if later corroborated by independent evidence, as seen in cases like Oregon v. Elstad.
The 'fruit of the poisonous tree' doctrine generally prohibits using evidence derived from coerced confessions, limiting the applicability of such exceptions.
Police may use psychological pressure that doesn't meet legal definitions of coercion, resulting in confessions that are technically admissible.
Modern courts increasingly recognize subtle coercion tactics and have expanded protections against psychologically manipulative interrogation methods.

supporting.text: International human rights standards, such as those under the UN Convention Against Torture, prohibit the use of coerced confessions in legal proceedings.

attacks.text: International human rights standards, such as those under the UN Convention Against Torture, prohibit the use of coerced confessions in legal proceedings.
Some countries do not fully adhere to international human rights standards, and coerced confessions may still be admitted in their legal systems.
Even in countries that do not fully adhere, international pressure and treaties can influence domestic courts to exclude coerced confessions.
The definition of 'coercion' can vary between jurisdictions, leading to inconsistent application of the prohibition.
International legal bodies provide guidelines to standardize the definition of coercion, reducing inconsistency.

supporting.text: Coerced confessions are unreliable as they may be false, undermining the integrity of the judicial process.

attacks.text: Coerced confessions are unreliable as they may be false, undermining the integrity of the judicial process.
Some coerced confessions may still contain truthful information, especially if corroborated by other evidence.
Even if partially true, coerced confessions risk contaminating the judicial process by introducing doubt about their validity.
Judges and juries can evaluate the reliability of confessions, including coerced ones, based on the totality of evidence.
Psychological research shows that people often cannot reliably distinguish between coerced and voluntary confessions.

supporting.text: Many jurisdictions have explicit legal provisions excluding evidence obtained through coercion to uphold fair trial principles.

attacks.text: Many jurisdictions have explicit legal provisions excluding evidence obtained through coercion to uphold fair trial principles.
Some jurisdictions lack clear enforcement mechanisms for these provisions, allowing coerced confessions to slip through.
International human rights bodies often monitor and pressure jurisdictions to enforce anti-coercion laws effectively.
Even with provisions, proving coercion can be difficult if interrogations are not recorded.
Mandatory recording of interrogations is becoming more widespread, reducing this loophole.

supporting.text: The due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment requires that confessions be given freely and voluntarily to be admissible.

attacks.text: The due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment requires that confessions be given freely and voluntarily to be admissible.
Some courts have admitted coerced confessions if the coercion was not extreme and the confession was later corroborated by independent evidence.
The 'fruit of the poisonous tree' doctrine generally excludes evidence derived from coerced confessions, even if the confession itself is corroborated.
The voluntariness standard is subjective and varies by jurisdiction, leading to inconsistent application of the Fourteenth Amendment requirement.
Supreme Court rulings like Brown v. Mississippi (1936) have established clear federal standards for voluntariness, reducing inconsistency.
